titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Charles H. Hapgood Papers
titlestmt.author: by Sandra Markham

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Saturday April 27, 2019 at 03:04

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: The Charles H. Hapgood Papers consist of correspondence, manuscripts, and research materials related to Hapgood's research projects and publications on earth science, archeology, ancient history, parapsychology, and spirit communication.

langmaterial.language: Materials in English, French, German, Spanish, and Arabic.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.
Box 39 contains restricted fragile material. Reference surrogates have been substituted in the main files. For further information consult the appropriate curator.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Charles H. Hapgood Papers is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Charles H. Hapgood Papers. Yale Collection of American Literature, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Hapgood had created many duplicates of the letters he wrote and received by means of mimeograph and carbon copies; he also created duplicates of chapters he transcribed from textbooks, as well as several duplicate transcripts of spirit communications. These duplicates were compared, removed, and discarded when the collection was processed.

relatedmaterial.head: Associated Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Additional Charles H. Hapgood material can be found in the Hapgood Family Papers (YCAL MSS 41) and the Miriam Hapgood DeWitt Papers (YCAL MSS 277) at the Beinecke Library, and the Hapgood Family Papers (manuscript group 795) in Manuscripts and Archives, Yale University Library. Additional material related to Hapgood's work with the medium Elwood Babbitt, as well as the manuscripts of his books on psychic studies, are in the Charles Hapgood Papers (MS 445) at the W. E. B. Du Bois Library, University of Massachusetts.

bioghist.head: Charles Hutchins Hapgood (1904-1982)
bioghist.p: Charles Hutchins Hapgood was the son of the journalists and authors Hutchins Hapgood (1869-1944) and Neith Boyce (1872-1951). He was born in New York City on May 17, 1904, and, along with his siblings Harry Boyce (1901-1918), Miriam (1906-1990), and Beatrix (1910-1994), was raised in the family's homes in New York and Provincetown, Massachusetts. Hapgood attended the Scarborough School in Westchester County, New York, and then, like his father, earned two degrees at Harvard University: an A.B. (1929) and M.A. (1932). Staying on in Cambridge, he completed the course requirements for a history Ph.D. but not his dissertation. After holding an administrative job at the Provincetown Community Center, and wartime positions with the Office of Strategic Services and the American Red Cross in Washington, D.C., Hapgood began a twenty-year teaching career in the humanities through faculty appointments at Keystone College (1945-1947), Springfield College (1947-1952), Keene State College (1956-1966), and New England College (1966-1967), where he lectured in world and American history, anthropology, economics, and the history of science.

Throughout his academic career, as well as in his retirement years, Hapgood pursued personal research projects that centered on controversial, and largely disputed, topics. His first published work was The Earth's Shifting Crust: a Key to Some Basic Problems of Earth Sciences (1958), which was revised and reissued in 1970 as The Path of the Pole . In these books he explored his theories about the movements of the outer layer of the earth and the resulting polar shifts, which he believed to have influenced the formation of various mountain ranges and the changing size and level of the oceans and seas. Hapgood's follow-up work, Maps of the Ancient Sea Kings: Evidence of Advanced Civilization in the Ice Age (1966, revised edition 1979), suggested that Antarctica had been a habitable continent prior to the shift of the earth's outer layer. His research was based in large part on a portolan chart drawn in 1513 by Piri Reis, a Turkish admiral and cartographer, which had been discovered in 1929 in an Istanbul library. Hapgood had earlier given a presentation on the map at the Tenth International Congress of the History of Science (Ithaca, New York, 1962). His continuing interest in ancient civilizations led to his publication Mystery in Acámbaro: an account of the ceramic collection of the late Waldemar Julsrud in Acámbaro, Gto., Mexico (1973), which discussed the more than 30,000 clay figures that had been excavated there in the summer of 1944; Hapgood supported Julsrud's belief that the figures (representing humans from a variety of civilizations, as well as dinosaurs), which were found in near-perfect condition, had been created and buried several thousand years before. However, most academics believed them to be a hoax, and made for Julsrud by twentieth-century Mexican peasants. In addition to these works, Hapgood reached the general public through articles he wrote for the Saturday Evening Post and Coronet magazines, and with his book for children, Great Mysteries of the Earth , which was published in 1960; it was also issued in Arabic.

Concurrent with his investigations in the fields of earth science, ancient history, and archeology, Hapgood was actively interested in parapsychology and spirit communication. He spent a decade working with the New England medium Elwood Babbitt (1921-2001) to encounter nearly sixty notables in divinity and history, both recent and ancient. The conversations were taped and transcribed, and provided Hapgood with material for his final three books: Voices of Spirit, Through the Psychic Experience of Elwood Babbitt (1975), Talks with Christ and His Teachers Through the Psychic Gift of Elwood Babbitt (1981), and The God Within: a Testament of Vishnu, a Handbook for the Spiritual Renaissance (1982).

Charles Hapgood's 1941 marriage to Tamsin Hughes (1906-1998) ended in divorce in 1955. In his later years he resided in Arizona and in Richmond, New Hampshire, but was living in Greenfield, Massachusetts, when he was struck by a car and died on December 21, 1982. Charles and Tamsin Hapgood were survived by two sons, Frederick (born 1942) and William (born 1944), and two grandsons.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Charles H. Hapgood Papers consist of correspondence, manuscripts, and research materials related to Hapgood's research projects and publications on earth science, archeology, ancient history, parapsychology, and spirit communication. The bulk of the material is letters from and to a wide array of people interested in Hapgood's work and theories, or, in some cases, those in whom he hoped to create an interest. His correspondents ranged from amateur geologists and local historians to respected scholars from around the world, as Hapgood's interests were equally wide-ranging: ancient maps to New Age philosophies, terrestrial science to celestial spirits. The collection holds little in the way of Hapgood family papers, although solid insight on Charles Hapgood's personality and personal life can be gleaned from many of his outgoing letters.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is organized into three series: I. Personal Papers (1913-1979); II. Writings (1918-1979); and Other Papers (1898-1979).

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into three subseries: Family Correspondence and Papers; Hutchins Hapgood and Neith Boyce Estates; and General Correspondence.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series contains material that is both personal and professional in nature, primarily letters written between Hapgood and his sisters, aunt, and other family members, and between Hapgood and his friends and colleagues. The Family Correspondence and Papers also contains Hapgood's international certificate of vaccination, and a group of newspaper articles about him and his work. The subseries Hutchins Hapgood and Neith Boyce Estates contains letters between Charles Hapgood and researchers working with his parents' papers, and typed transcripts of some of his father's essays. More extensive correspondence with the same people and others related to the management of the Hapgood and Boyce literary estates can be found in the Miriam Hapgood DeWitt Papers (YCAL MSS 277).

While the bulk of the letters relating to Charles Hapgood's research and publications are held in Series II Writings, the subseries of General Correspondence here contains files for people with whom Hapgood had professional relationships that spanned both many years and his various research projects, such as Robert Merritt, Ivan Sanderson, and his agent, Oliver Swan, as well as publishers Alfred A. Knopf and the Chilton Book Company. Also here are letters from former students, and long-time friends such as his high school classmate Jack Frankland. Intimate details of Hapgood's personal and financial affairs can be found in the correspondence with his lawyer, Arthur A. Atha. Copies of obituaries written for Hapgood are in the papers of his sister Miriam Hapgood DeWitt (YCAL MSS 277).

arrangement.head: Arrangement

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series contains correspondence and subject files supporting Hapgood's research projects and writings, as well as manuscripts, drafts, and galley sheets related to the production of his books; files related to the latter appear at the start of each subseries, followed by correspondence and subject files, if there are any. The subject files hold academic and research material such as journal offprints, drawings, slides, and photographs sent to Hapgood, some at his request and others to substantiate the writer's points. Hapgood also had transcribed entire chapters of books, and put the copies (some in carbon, others in mimeograph) in the correspondence files under the author's name. In one case, a typed copy of a short Turkish book on the Piri Reis map was made so that it could be distributed to his students via the then-popular medium of mimeograph. Because Hapgood's topics and consultants were somewhat overlapping in time and scope, material related to one subseries may also appear in the other subseries. In addition, some correspondence related to his research is filed in the General Correspondence subseries of Series I, so readers are encouraged to look there as well, if attempting to locate all information on a particular project.

Material in the subseries Archeology pertains primarily to Hapgood's work on the clay figures discovered in Acámbaro, Mexico. Of note here is a decade's worth of letters from Erle Stanley Gardner (1889-1970), a respected author of detective fiction, who was interested enough in the mystery of the figurines to provide financial support for Hapgood's investigation. The Children's Books subseries has files on Hapgood's published work Great Mysteries of the Earth , as well as proposals and drafts of his unpublished story "The Little Rhinoceros."

The subseries Earth's Shifting Crust contains files related to that 1958 title as well as its revised edition, The Path of the Pole (1971), in which Hapgood made use of up-to-date technological advancements to support his theories of continental drift and climate change. The subseries Maps of the Ancient Sea Kings includes material related to Hapgood's book, and shorter writings on the Piri Reis map and other portolan charts, as well as information about unusual aerial phenomena (UFOs).

Material in the subseries Psychic Studies is arranged under three headings: Correspondence; Spirit Communications; and Subject Files. This subseries contains transcripts, voiceprints, and one tape recording of sessions held with the medium Elwood Babbitt, as well as a file on hospital tests that Hapgood had conducted on Babbitt. It also includes a number of research papers written by Hapgood's college students, describing experiments on the effect of musical and mental projections on the growth of plants and the actions of household pets.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into three subseries: Eleanor Roosevelt; Teaching Files; and Miscellaneous Papers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series primarily contains correspondence and subject files related to Hapgood's interests outside of his research and writing, in particular a selection of material documenting his concerns during World War II and his teaching career. Hapgood wrote letters to Eleanor Roosevelt on several topics between 1939 and 1960; her replies were not particularly substantive. Their correspondence is filed here by subject.

The Teaching Files subseries primarily holds reading lists, notes, student papers, and syllabi, and a folder of curriculum vitae assembled by Hapgood. Additional student papers and course materials are filed within Series II, Writings, by subject. The folder with material from Hapgood's United States history course contains the earliest piece in the collection: a letter written during the Spanish-American War by a soldier in the 1st Vermont Regiment stationed at Camp George H. Thomas, Chickamauga Park, Georgia. Its relationship to Hapgood or his family is unknown.

Miscellaneous Papers contains random material unrelated to Hapgood's research and writings. Also filed here is a photocopy of an autobiographical narrative; although it was in a file folder with Fred Hapgood's name on it, the description of Charles Hapgood within it makes it seems unlikely that it was written by him.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains mostly carbon copies of letters to and from Roosevelt, likely made before Hapgood gave the originals to the Smithsonian Institution in 1969
